Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Simulation Training on Catheter Skills Acquisition in Surgical Residents

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups

Intervention.evidence: 10 residents received additional training with the Procedicus computer-based haptic simulator, while 10 served as controls

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the impact of simulation on the acquisition of catheter skills by surgical residents.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was resident performance during two consecutive mentored catheter-based interventions

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence

Blinding.evidence: attending surgeons blinded to training status graded performance

Result_Outcome.evidence: Residents exposed to simulation scored higher than controls during the first intervention: procedural steps (50 ± 6 vs. 33 ± 9, P = 0.0015); global rating scale (30 ± 7 vs. 19 ± 5, P = 0.0052).
